questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. A rapid antigen detection test for Group A Streptococcus is positive. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe oral penicillin V for 10 days

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a throat culture to confirm the diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: Administer a single dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.correct_answer: A. Prescribe oral penicillin V for 10 days
questions.explanation:
Gram Stain

Gram-positive cocci in chains

Appearance on Blood Agar
  • Pinpoint colonies with a wide zone of hemolysis
  • Indicates beta-hemolysis

Transport Medium

Pike's media

Selective Media

PNF (Phenylethyl alcohol agar), Crystal Violet Blood Agar (CVBA)

Liquid Media
  • Granular turbidity
  • Suggests the presence of streptococci, as these organisms can cause cloudiness in liquid media.

Biochemical Tests

Result
  • Catalase Test

Negative
  • Oxidase Test

Negative
  • PYR Test

Positive
  • Bacitracin Sensitivity

Sensitive

Antibiotic

Dosage (Children)

Dosage (Adolescents/Adults)

Special Notes

Penicillin V (Oral)

250 mg 2–3 times daily for 10 days

250 mg 4 times daily or 500 mg twice daily for 10 days

First-line oral treatment; is effective and inexpensive.

Amoxicillin (Oral)
  • 50 mg/kg once daily (max 1000 mg) or 25 mg/kg twice daily (max 500 mg) for 10 days

N/A

Preferred for younger children due to better palatability; similar efficacy to penicillin.

Benzathine Penicillin G (IM)
  • 600,000 U (for children <27 kg) 1 dose
  • 1,200,000 U (for children ≥27 kg) 1 dose

N/A

For patients who cannot tolerate oral therapy or have poor adherence to a 10-day regimen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a persistent cough and purulent sputum. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and frequent respiratory infections. A sputum sample is sent for culture, which grows a gram-negative diplococcus that is oxidase positive and butyrate esterase positive. What is the most likely pathogen?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Moraxella Catarrhalis

Moraxella Lacunata (axenfeld)

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci

Gram-negative coccobacilli

Growth on Blood Agar and Chocolate Agar

Smooth, opaque, grayish-white colonies

Smooth, spreading colonies with a pit in the center

Catalase Test

Positive

Positive

Oxidase Test

Positive

Positive

DNase Test

Positive

Negative

Butyrate Esterase Test

Positive

Negative

Nitrate Reduction Test

Positive

Positive

Sugar Fermentation

Does not ferment sugars

Does not ferment sugars

Common Infections

Otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia

Conjunctivitis (not a common pathogen)

Virulence Factors

Beta-lactamase production, immune evasion mechanisms

Less characterized

Typical Symptoms

Ear pain, nasal congestion, cough, fever, respiratory distress

Redness, itching, discharge from the eyes

Transmission

Respiratory droplets

Direct contact with contaminated surfaces or secretions

Antibiotic Susceptibility

Generally susceptible to beta-lactamase inhibitors, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones

Typically sensitive to similar antibiotics but less commonly treated due to lower pathogenicity

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 5-day history of dysuria and purulent urethral discharge. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. Gram stain of the urethral discharge reveals gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents to the emergency department with high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and a petechial rash. Lumbar puncture is performed, and the CSF analysis shows elevated white blood cell count with a predominance of neutrophils, elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. Gram stain reveals gram-negative diplococci, confirming Neisseria meningitidis. What is the most appropriate initial empirical antibiotic therapy for this patient?
Which of the following findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) would most strongly suggest a diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Low Neutrophil count, normal protein, normal glucose

options.label: B
options.text: High Neutrophil count, high protein, low glucose

options.label: C
options.text: High Neutrophil count, low protein, normal glucose

options.label: D
options.text: Low Neutrophil count, high protein, high glucose

questions.correct_answer: B. High Neutrophil count, high protein, low glucose
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Findings

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis
  • Appearance

Cloudy or purulent
  • White Blood Cell Count (WBC)

Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils
  • Protein

Elevated
  • Glucose

Decreased
  • Gram Stain

Presence of gram-negative diplococci
  • Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA
  • Latex Agglutination Test

Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens

Blood Tests
  • Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis
  • White Blood Cell Count

Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

Parameter

Bacterial Meningitis

Viral (Aseptic) Meningitis

Fungal Meningitis

Tuberculous Meningitis

Appearance

Cloudy or purulent

Clear or slightly cloudy

Clear or slightly cloudy

Clear or slightly cloudy, Cob web coagulum

White Blood Cell Count
  • Elevated (usually >1,000 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly neutrophils (≥80%)
  • Elevated (usually 50-1,000 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly lymphocytes
  • Elevated (usually 20-500 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly lymphocytes
  • Elevated (usually 50-500 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly lymphocytes

Protein

Elevated (100-500 mg/dL)

Mildly elevated or normal (50-100 mg/dL)

Elevated (100-500 mg/dL)

Elevated (100-500 mg/dL)

Glucose

Decreased (<40 mg/dL or <2.2 mmol/L)

Normal or slightly decreased

Decreased

Decreased

CSF/Blood Glucose Ratio

<0.4

>0.6

<0.4

<0.4

Opening Pressure

Elevated

Normal or slightly elevated

Elevated

Elevated

Gram Stain

Positive for bacteria (gram-negative diplococci, etc.)

Negative

Negative

Negative

questions.text: Which of the following tests would best help to differentiate Neisseria meningitidis from Neisseria gonorrhoeae in this clinical context?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Neisseria meningitidis

Morphology

Gram-negative diplococci

Kidney shaped

Gram-negative diplococci with capsule

Oxidase Test

Positive

Positive

Catalase Test

Positive

Positive

Habitat

Human genitourinary tract

Human nasopharynx

Transmission

Sexual contact

Respiratory droplets, close contact

Diseases Caused

Gonorrhea, pelvic inflammatory disease, conjunctivitis in newborns

Meningitis, septicemia (meningococcemia)

Virulence Factors

Pili, outer membrane proteins, lipooligosaccharides (LOS)

Polysaccharide capsule, pili, outer membrane proteins, LOS

Culture Media

Thayer-Martin agar, Chocolate agar

Thayer-Martin agar, Chocolate agar

Carbohydrate Utilization

Glucose positive, maltose negative

Glucose positive, maltose positive

Superoxol Test

Strong positive with 30% hydrogen peroxide

Weak or negative reaction

Antibiotic Resistance

Increasing resistance, especially to penicillin and fluoroquinolones

Generally susceptible to penicillin, but resistance can occur

Vaccination

No vaccine available

Vaccines available for various serogroups (A, C, W, Y, B)

Epidemiology

Common STD worldwide

Causes outbreaks, especially in crowded settings

questions.text: A clinical microbiology laboratory is performing biochemical tests to identify a strain of gamma-hemolytic streptococci isolated from a blood culture. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to differentiate Streptococcus bovis from other gamma-hemolytic streptococci?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Relevance

Infections: Can cause a range of infections including urinary tract infections, bacteremia, intra-abdominal infections, and wound infections.

Endocarditis: Streptococcus bovis is particularly associated with infective endocarditis, often in patients with underlying gastrointestinal malignancies or colon disorders.

Laboratory Diagnosis

Gram Stain: Gram-positive oval cocci are often arranged in chains or pairs.

Culture:

  • Growth on blood agar without hemolysis.
  • Growth on Mac Conkey medium- tiny magenta colony

Biochemical Tests: Differentiation within the group using tests like bile esculin agar (positive for Enterococcus), PYR test (positive for Enterococcus), and other biochemical markers.

Treatment

Antibiotics: Generally susceptible to penicillin and ampicillin, although some strains, especially within the Enterococcus genus, may exhibit resistance to multiple antibiotics.

Treatment of Endocarditis: Combination therapy with aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) is often used for synergy, particularly in cases of enterococcal endocarditis.

Epidemiology

Common in the gastrointestinal tract, especially in elderly or immunocompromised patients

Streptococcus bovis is associated with colorectal cancer and inflammatory bowel disease, warranting screening for these conditions in patients with the bacterium

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to her primary care physician for an annual check-up. She asks about vaccines recommended for adults to prevent pneumonia. Which of the following vaccines would be most appropriate to recommend to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment for Strep Pneumoniae

Vaccines for Strep Pneumoniae
  • Penicillin and Penicillin Derivatives: Effective for susceptible strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae. High-dose penicillin G or amoxicillin is the treatment of choice for non-severe infections.
  • Cephalosporins: Such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime are used for more severe infections or in patients with penicillin allergy.
  • Macrolides: Such as erythromycin or azithromycin, may be used in cases of resistance or intolerance to beta-lactams.

Supportive care including antipyretics, oxygen therapy, and fluids as needed.

Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV): Contains polysaccharide antigens from the most common serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a carrier protein.

  • Recommended for infants and young children to prevent invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), pneumonia, and otitis media.(Option A ruled out)
  • It's a seven-valent conjugate vaccine.

Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine (PPSV):

  • Covers a broader range of pneumococcal serotypes compared to PCV.
  • Recommended for adults over 65 years old, and younger adults with certain medical conditions (e.g., immunocompromised, chronic heart or lung disease).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, productive cough with rust-colored sputum, and pleuritic chest pain. His medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A chest X-ray reveals a lobar consolidation. Sputum Gram stain shows gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on the sputum

options.label: D
options.text: Bile solubility test on the sputum sample

questions.explanation:
Pneumonia

Community-acquired pneumonia, is often characterized by rapid onset, high fever, chills, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough with rust-colored sputum.

Meningitis

A common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults and children, presenting with symptoms like headache, fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, and altered mental status.

Otitis Media

A frequent cause of middle ear infections in children, characterized by ear pain, fever, irritability, and sometimes hearing loss.

Sinusitis

Causes acute sinus infections, presenting with facial pain, nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, and fever.

Endocarditis

Can cause endocarditis, particularly in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions.

Gram Stain:
  • Gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci.
  • Useful in the initial identification of clinical specimens like sputum, blood, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

Culture
  • Grows well on blood agar, producing alpha-hemolytic (greenish) colonies.
  • Optochin sensitivity test: S. pneumoniae is sensitive to optochin, differentiating it from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci.
  • Bile solubility test: S. pneumoniae is bile soluble, confirming its identity

Blood Culture

  • Critical for diagnosing invasive pneumococcal disease and guiding antibiotic therapy.

Antigen Detection:
  • Latex agglutination or immunochromatographic tests for pneumococcal antigens in urine or CSF.
  • Rapid diagnostic tool, especially useful in meningitis cases.

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
  • Detection of pneumococcal DNA in clinical specimens.
  • Highly sensitive and specific, useful for diagnosing invasive pneumococcal disease

Quellung Reaction:
  • Capsular swelling test where specific antisera cause the capsule of S. pneumoniae to swell, confirming its presence and serotype

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease and a prosthetic mitral valve undergoes a tooth extraction. Two weeks later, she presents with fever, night sweats, and malaise. Blood cultures reveal alpha-hemolytic Streptococcus viridans. Transesophageal echocardiography shows vegetations on the mitral valve. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start oral amoxicillin and schedule follow-up in one week.

options.label: B
options.text: Admit to the hospital and start intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin.

options.label: C
options.text: Discharge with a prescription for oral clindamycin and instruct her to return if symptoms worsen.

questions.correct_answer: B. Admit to the hospital and start intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin.
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology:
  • Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis.
  • Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk.

Infection Mechanism:
  • Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics.
  • Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues.

Clinical Presentation:
  • Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages.
  • Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction.

Diagnosis:
  • Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism.
  • Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves

Treatment:
  • Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves.

questions.text: A 36-week pregnant woman presents for routine prenatal care. Her GBS culture from 35 weeks gestation is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient during labor?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer intravenous ampicillin every 4 hours until delivery

options.label: B
options.text: Prescribe oral penicillin for 7 days prior to expected delivery date

options.label: C
options.text: Administer a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone at the onset of labor

options.label: D
options.text: No antibiotic prophylaxis needed; treat the newborn empirically after birth

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer intravenous ampicillin every 4 hours until delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation undergoes routine screening for Group B Streptococcus (GBS). The vaginal-rectal swab culture shows beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm GBS?

options.label: B
options.text: Conduct a latex agglutination test for group B antigen

questions.text: A full-term newborn develops respiratory distress, lethargy, and poor feeding within 24 hours of birth. The mother had no prenatal care. Blood culture grows gram-positive cocci in chains. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Early-onset Group B Streptococcal disease
questions.explanation:
Condition

Onset

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Complications

Neonatal Sepsis

Early-Onset (0-6 days)/ Late-Onset (7-89 days)

Fever, irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, respiratory distress

Blood cultures, CSF analysis, PCR

Ampicillin + gentamicin or cefotaxime

Meningitis, pneumonia, death

Neonatal Meningitis

Late-Onset (7-89 days)

Fever, irritability, poor feeding, bulging fontanelle

CSF analysis, blood cultures, PCR

Ampicillin + gentamicin or cefotaxime

Neurological sequelae, hydrocephalus, death

Neonatal Pneumonia

Early-Onset (0-6 days)

Respiratory distress, tachypnea, grunting, cyanosis

Chest X-ray, blood cultures, PCR

Ampicillin + gentamicin or cefotaxime

Respiratory failure, sepsis, death

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has a purulent discharge from a surgical wound after an abdominal surgery performed two weeks ago. An analysis of the discharge, reveals Gram-positive cocci. Further testing shows that the organism is catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?

A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and rash that started on the neck and chest and then spread to the trunk and extremities. Examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Complications

Pharyngitis

Sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes

Throat culture, rapid antigen detection test

Penicillin, amoxicillin, cephalosporins

Rheumatic fever, acute glomerulonephritis

Scarlet Fever

(Option B)

Rash, fever, strawberry tongue

Clinical presentation, throat culture

Penicillin, erythromycin

Rheumatic fever, septicemia

Impetigo- Non-bullous

Honey-crusted lesions on the face and limbs

Clinical presentation, culture of lesions

Topical mupirocin, oral antibiotics

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Erysipelas

(Option D)

Raised, well-demarcated erythematous lesions

Clinical presentation, blood cultures

Penicillin, erythromycin

Bacteremia, septicemia

Cellulitis

Diffuse, spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue

Clinical presentation, blood cultures

Penicillin, clindamycin, cephalosporins

Necrotizing fasciitis, sepsis

Necrotizing Fasciitis

Severe pain, swelling, fever, rapid spread of infection

Clinical presentation, imaging studies

Surgical debridement, broad-spectrum antibiotics

Septic shock, multi-organ failure

Streptococcal Toxic Shock Syndrome (STSS)

(Option C)

Fever, hypotension, multi-organ involvement

Clinical presentation, blood cultures

IV fluids, vasopressors, broad-spectrum antibiotics

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

Acute Rheumatic Fever

Migratory arthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum

Clinical criteria (Jones criteria), throat culture

Penicillin, anti-inflammatory drugs (aspirin)

Chronic rheumatic heart disease

Acute glomerulonephritis

Hematuria, proteinuria, edema, hypertension

Clinical presentation, urine analysis

Supportive care, antihypertensives

Chronic kidney disease

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Throat culture grows beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, and the isolate is identified as Streptococcus pyogenes. Which of the following virulence factors of S. pyogenes is primarily responsible for its ability to resist phagocytosis and contribute to invasive infections?
questions.explanation:
Virulence Factor

Description

Mechanism of Action

Associated Diseases

M Protein

(Option B)

Surface protein

Resists phagocytosis by inhibiting opsonization, interacts with host cell receptors
  • Pharyngitis,
  • rheumatic fever

Streptolysin O and S (Option A)

Hemolysins

Lyse red and white blood cells, and platelets; cause tissue damage
  • Pharyngitis,
  • skin infections

Streptococcal Pyrogenic Exotoxins (SPEs)

Exotoxins

Act as superantigens, causing a massive immune response; associated with scarlet fever and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome
  • Scarlet fever,
  • toxic shock-like syndrome (TSLS)

Hyaluronidase

(Option D)

Enzyme

Degrades hyaluronic acid in the host's connective tissue, facilitating bacterial spread
  • Cellulitis,
  • necrotizing fasciitis

Streptokinase

(Option C)

Enzyme

Converts plasminogen to plasmin, dissolving blood clots and facilitating spread
  • Deep tissue infections,
  • pharyngitis

DNases (A, B, C, D)

Enzymes

Depolymerize free DNA in pus, reducing viscosity and aiding the spread
  • Abscess formation,
  • skin infections

C5a Peptidase

Enzyme

Degrades the C5a component of the complement system, inhibiting chemotaxis of phagocytes
  • Immune evasion,
  • systemic infections

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule

Composed of hyaluronic acid; inhibits phagocytosis
  • Severe invasive diseases,
  • immune evasion

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a persistent fever and septicemia. Blood cultures show alpha-hemolytic growth on blood agar. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Hemolytic Activity

Example Species

Characteristics

Alpha-hemolytic

S. pneumoniae, (Option C)

S. viridans

Partial hemolysis, greenish color

Beta-hemolytic

S. pyogenes, (Option A)

S. agalactiae (Option B)

Complete hemolysis, clear zone

Gamma-hemolytic

S. bovis, (Option D)

Enterococcus

No hemolysis

Lancefield Group

Key Species

Associated Infections

Group A

Streptococcus pyogenes

Strep throat, impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis, rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis

Group B

Streptococcus agalactiae

Neonatal meningitis, sepsis, infections in immunocompromised adults

Group C

Streptococcus equisimilis

Pharyngitis, endocarditis

Group F

Various Streptococcus species

Rare, "minute streptococci", infections in various body sites

Group G

Various Streptococcus species

Tonsillitis, endocarditis, urinary tract infections

questions.text: A 26-year-old sexually active female comes with complaints of burning micturition and haematuria. On investigation, the causative agent is a gram-positive coccus which is coagulase-negative. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Conditions caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis:

Bacteremia

Implanted foreign bodies

Cystitis

Compromised defenses

Bloodstream infections

Central lines

Endocarditis

Drug addicts

Condition caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus:

Urinary tract infections

Sexually active young women

Antibiotic resistance

Nalidixic acid, novobiocin

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a skin infection and he was started on benzylpenicillin. A culture was done when the patient failed to respond to the given treatment and methicillin resistance was detected. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Method

Description

Culture-based techniques

Use of chromogenic agar media where MRSA colonies appear pink, and other bacteria appear blue.

Blood Sample Testing
  • 10–20 ml of venous blood is drawn and injected into two culture bottles, incubated aerobically and anaerobically at 35°C.
  • Automated systems detect growth via turbidity, fluorescence, O2 consumption, or CO2 production.
  • Most bacteria are recovered within 2 days. Gram staining and specialized media are used for further identification.

CSF Sample Testing
  • For suspected meningitis, a lumbar puncture is performed to obtain 3–5 ml of CSF.
  • Turbidity and high leukocyte counts indicate infection.
  • CSF is Gram-stained and inoculated onto selective culture media.

Feature

VISA

VRSA

Full Name

Vancomycin-Intermediate Staphylococcus aureus

Vancomycin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus

Resistance Level

Intermediate resistance to vancomycin

High resistance to vancomycin

MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration)

4-8 µg/mL

≥ 16 µg/mL

Mechanism of Resistance

Thickened cell wall leading to reduced penetration of vancomycin

Acquisition of vanA gene from Enterococcus, altering the target site of vancomycin

Treatment Options

Higher doses of vancomycin, linezolid, daptomycin, or alternative agents

Linezolid, daptomycin, quinupristin-dalfopristin, or alternative agents

Prevalence

More common than VRSA, but still relatively rare

Very rare compared to VISA

Clinical Significance

This can lead to treatment failure with standard vancomycin dosing

Represents a significant therapeutic challenge due to high-level resistance

questions.text: Consider the following statements. Statement A: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other staphylococci species. Statement B: Differentiates tubercle bacilli from atypical mycobacteria and indicates isoniazid sensitivity.

options.label: A
options.text: Statement A is true for a catalase test.

options.label: B
options.text: Statement B is true for a coagulase test.

options.label: C
options.text: Statement A is true for a coagulase test.

options.label: D
options.text: Both statements are true for a catalase test.v

questions.correct_answer: C. Statement A is true for a coagulase test.
questions.explanation:
Coagulase Test:

Catalase Test:

Purpose: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other staphylococci species.

Methods:

  1. Tube Test:
  • Detects free coagulase (extracellular enzyme produced by S. aureus).
  • Bacterial culture mixed with plasma in a tube.
  • Positive if plasma clots.
    1. Slide Test:
  • Detects bound coagulase (clumping factor, bound to bacterial cell wall).
  • Bacteria mixed with plasma on a slide.
  • Positive if bacteria clump together.

Purpose: Tests for production of catalase enzyme. All Staphylococci produce catalase.

  • Catalase neutralises hydrogen peroxide’s antibacterial properties.
  • It differentiates staphylococci form streptococci

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with a chronic foot ulcer showing signs of infection. Which laboratory test is most appropriate for identifying the causative organism, suspected to be Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.explanation:
Step:

Description:

Specimen Collection
  • Pus samples from suppurative lesions, sputum for respiratory infections, nasal swabs for carriers

Direct Microscopy
  • Gram staining reveals Gram-positive cocci in clusters, indicating staphylococci presence (Option A)
  • Grape bunch- appearance

 

Culture
  • Culturing on blood agar to isolate and identify S. aureus colonies (Option C)
  • Blood agar: beta hemolysis
  • Nutrient agar: golden colonies

Selective Media
  • Salt-milk agar, Ludlam's medium, or Roberts' cooked meat medium to isolate S. aureus from mixed samples
  • Mannitol salt agar- yellow color from S. aureus fermenting mannitol

Biochemical Reactions
  • Coagulase test: Detects S. aureus by its ability to clot plasma (positive result indicates S. aureus)
  • Catalase test: Positive

Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing
  • Determines antibiotic sensitivity to guide treatment decisions (Option D)

Molecular Methods
  • PCR to detect specific genes like mecA, associated with antibiotic resistance (Option B)

Typing Method

Description

Examples

Phenotypic Typing
  • Relies on observable characteristics like antibiotic susceptibility or bacteriophage response.
  • Method: Classifies strains based on susceptibility to specific bacteriophages.
  • Limitations: Not all cultures are typeable; susceptibility patterns can change.

Bacteriophage typing

Genotypic Typing
  • Analyzes genetic characteristics of bacteria for strain differentiation.
  • Benefits: Offers higher discriminatory power, valuable in outbreak investigations.

DNA fingerprinting (e.g., RFLP, ribotyping)

PCR-based methods, PFGE, MLST

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with high fever, diffuse macular rash, hypotension, purulent vaginal discharge, and desquamation of the skin on her palms and soles. She has used tampons during her recent menstrual cycle and forgot to remove them on time. Laboratory tests reveal a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. Which toxin is primarily responsible for the condition observed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Disease caused by staphylococcus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin (Option B)

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option D)

questions.text: Bronchopneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus infection is suspected in a 40-year-old patient. Which diagnostic test utilizes protein A to detect the presence of this bacteria?

A 3-year-old child presents with fever, and widespread peeling of the skin, especially around the face and trunk. The causative organism is identified as a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive coccus. Which virulence factor of this organism is responsible for the clinical manifestation observed in this child?
questions.explanation:
Virulence factors

 

Key features

Cell wall-associated polymers

 

Peptidoglycan

 

Activates complement-induced release of inflammatory cytokines

Teichoic acid

Adherence to the host cell surface, and shields them from complement-mediated opsonization

Capsular polysaccharide

Inhibits opsonization

Cell surface

Protein A
  • Anti-complementary
  • Anti-phagocytic
  • Co-agglutination

Clumping factor

Responsible for the slide coagulase test

Toxins

Hemolysin (Option C)

Alpha hemolysin-

  • Lyse sheep and human red blood cells.
  • Toxic to macrophages, lysosomes, muscle tissues, the renal cortex, and the circulatory system

Beta-hemolysins or sphingomyelinase

  • Lyse sheep red blood cells only

Panton-Valentine (PVL) Leucocidin
  • Synergohymenotropic toxin
  • Attacks neutrophils, platelets
  • Produced by Methicillin-Resistant Staph. aureus (MRSA)

Enterotoxin (superantigen)
  • Food poisoning
  • Most cases are caused by type A.
  • It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system causing symptoms. Vomiting is stimulated in the brain stem.

Toxic shock syndrome toxin(TSST) (Option D) (superantigen)
  • Fatal multisystem disease
  • Tampon-related TSS

Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin (Option A)
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): the outer layer of the epidermis gets separated from the underlying tissues.
  • Severe form of SSSS: Ritter's disease in the newborn and toxic epidermal necrolysis in older patients.
  • Milder forms: pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo

Enzymes

Coagulase (Option B)

Clotting of human or rabbit plasma

Lipid hydrolases

Helps in skin and subcutaneous tissue infections

Hyaluronidase
  • Breaks down the connective tissues
  • Staphylokinase, protease

Nuclease

Heat-stable DNase

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a purulent discharge from the wound. The laboratory identifies the causative bacteria to be gram-positive cocci, non-motile, non-spore-forming, catalase-positive, and coagulase-positive. Which notable characteristic of this organism is seen when cultured on nutrient agar helps in diagnosis?
